http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Theatre I is a two-semester course in which students learn and demonstrate mastery of theatre academic and performance skills. Theatre II and III are two-semester courses which expand the knowledge and performance base of Theatre I. At the Theatre I level, students will explore theatre fundamentals, analyze and interpret scripts, evaluate artistic work, and use those evaluations to deepen the meaning of their work. In Theatre II and III students will focus on the practical application of skills developed in Theatre I. Students will take on more complex projects and may begin to develop directorial skills. Ultimately, students will make artistic decisions using multiple forms of inspiration, particularly focusing on social, cultural, and historical context. Theatre I contains an introduction to stagecraft skills. Theatre II and III do not develop these stagecraft skills, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Stagecraft I-III Curriculum Framework. Theatre I fulfills the one-half credit fine arts required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Theatre I, Theatre II, and Theatre III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
Explore imaginary environments through dramatic activities (e.g., pantomime, mime, improvisation) to develop diverse characters through collaboration
Collaborate to prepare an informal or formal performance

Generate multiple designs for a single drama/theatre work, following the steps of the design process
  • analysis
  • research
  • preliminary sketches
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.
Develop characters, environments, and actions individually and in groups to create a desired effect in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work

Utilize appropriate terminology in regard to stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage

Investigate the various onstage and offstage theatrical jobs and the responsibilities of each
  • actor
  • designer
  • director
  • playwright
  • producer
  • stage manager
  • technician
Describe the impact of theatre spaces on performances
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Create selected theatrical paperwork

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, audition forms

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Modify choices based on self and peer evaluations of artistic work
Performing
Students will analyze, interpret, and select artistic work for presentation.
Analyze a script of literary merit to interpret characters and visual design elements
Analyze the manner in which a character's unique choices make drama/theatre work believable
Interpret characters based on research from multiple sources of information

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., print resources, web resources, film, video

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Relate character objectives and tactics to a drama/theatre work
Analyze the relationship of the elements of drama in a specific devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Refine a believable, authentic, and relevant performance of a drama/theatre work through physical, vocal, and psychological choices
Create empathetic characters in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Apply theatrical skills and techniques through the rehearsal process

Refine a drama/theatre work following steps in the acting process
  • analysis
  • research
  • vocal/movement choices
  • character choices
  • rehearsal
Apply the characteristics of a strong and versatile stage voice
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Utilize appropriate safety practices in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., personal protective equipment, proper use of tools and chemicals, situational awareness, exit procedures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Convey a specific meaning through the performance of a devised or scripted drama/theatre work for a specific audience
Share a created concept for a devised or scripted drama/theatre work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., character analysis, scene analysis, artistic vision

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Analyze the consequences of a character's decisions and actions
Analyze the authenticity of character interactions
Analyze the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Analyze dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using theatre terminology
Respond appropriately to a theatrical experience as an audience member
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Compare emotional responses evoked by a variety of genres
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

Apply criteria using theatre terminology to evaluate performances and/or designs
  • peer
  • self
  • stage, film, and/or television
Research the manner in which society determines artistic merit
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Evaluate the impact of personal experience on the creation of drama/theatre work
Employ knowledge of acting theories (e.g., internal, external, integrated, method) in the creation of drama/theatre work
Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Make personal artistic choices based on societal, cultural, and historical contexts
Analyze the influence (e.g., design choices, acting choices, directing choices) of cultural perspectives and theatrical conventions/practices on theatre art
Analyze the effect of theatre on the beliefs, attitudes, and actions of people of various ages and cultures
Develop cultural sensitivity to the artistic work of others
Analyze the influence of community values and beliefs in the creation of drama/theatre work
Employ knowledge of theatre history to increase the impact of student-created drama/theatre work
Design a theatre experience using other art forms and media
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Utilize available technological resources to increase the impact of a drama/theatre work
